ayahs.text:
This verse opens with the term 'Al-Haqqah' - that which surely comes to pass! This refers to the Day of Judgment, whose occurrence is an established truth and an absolute reality about which there is no doubt whatsoever. The term emphasizes the inevitability and certainty of the Day of Resurrection.

The name 'Al-Haqqah' captures the essence of the Day of Judgment as the ultimate truth that will manifest itself, when all falsehood will be exposed and all reality will become clear. This day represents the fulfillment of divine promise and the actualization of divine justice, making it the most certain event in existence.

This verse repeats the opening declaration, asking 'What is Al-Haqqah?' This repetition serves to emphasize the magnitude and significance of the Day of Judgment. The interrogative form draws attention to the extraordinary nature of this event and prepares the listener for further explanation.

The repetition also creates a sense of anticipation and wonder, highlighting that this day is beyond ordinary human comprehension. The verse structure mirrors similar patterns found in other chapters of the Quran where momentous events are introduced with repeated questioning to emphasize their overwhelming significance.

This verse continues the pattern of emphasis by asking 'And what will make you understand what Al-Haqqah is?' This rhetorical question underscores the human inability to fully comprehend the magnitude and reality of the Day of Judgment. It emphasizes that the true nature of this day is beyond normal human understanding.

The verse implies that even with explanation and description, the full reality of the Day of Judgment cannot be completely grasped by the human mind in this worldly state. This creates humility before the divine and emphasizes the need for faith in accepting the reality of what is to come, even when it exceeds our capacity for complete understanding.

This verse begins recounting historical examples of nations that rejected the truth, specifically mentioning that the tribes of Thamud and 'Ad denied Al-Qari'ah (The Striking Calamity). Al-Qari'ah is another name for the Day of Judgment, derived from the root meaning to strike, knock, or shatter something forcefully.

The connection between Al-Haqqah and Al-Qari'ah is significant, as both terms refer to the Day of Judgment but emphasize different aspects. While Al-Haqqah emphasizes its inevitability and truth, Al-Qari'ah emphasizes its powerful, striking nature that will shatter all false securities and expose all realities. The mention of these ancient peoples serves as a warning that denial of divine truth leads to destruction.

This verse describes the destruction of the Thamud people through 'At-Taghiyah' - an overwhelming transgressing calamity. The term implies something that goes beyond all limits and boundaries, representing an extreme and devastating form of divine punishment that exceeded all normal measures.

The Quran uses various terms to describe the punishment that befell Thamud, including earthquake (Ar-Rajfah), thunderous blast (As-Sayhah), and lightning strike (Sa'iqah), all indicating different aspects or intensities of the divine punishment. This verse emphasizes that their destruction was comprehensive and beyond any natural disaster they could have anticipated or prepared for.

This verse describes the destruction of the 'Ad people through a violent, roaring wind. The emphasis is on the overwhelming nature of this wind that was sent as divine punishment for their rejection of truth and their prophet Hud. The wind was not merely a natural phenomenon but a directed instrument of divine judgment.

The description highlights how divine punishment can come through natural elements that are transformed into instruments of justice. The 'Ad people, who were known for their physical strength and impressive constructions, were completely overwhelmed by this wind, demonstrating that no human power can stand against divine decree when the time of reckoning arrives.

This verse provides specific details about the destruction of the 'Ad people, explaining that Allah subjected them to the violent wind for seven consecutive nights and eight consecutive days without pause. The wind continued relentlessly in its work of complete destruction, leaving no respite for the people to escape or find shelter.

The verse describes how one could see the people lying prostrate as if they were hollow trunks of palm trees. This comparison is particularly apt because the 'Ad people were known for their tall stature, and the image of fallen palm trunks conveys both their physical appearance in death and the completeness of their destruction. The specific time period emphasizes the thoroughness of divine punishment.

This verse continues the description of the 'Ad people's destruction, reiterating the image of them lying scattered like hollow trunks of palm trees. The repetition emphasizes the completeness of their annihilation and serves as a powerful visual reminder of the consequences of rejecting divine guidance.

The comparison to palm tree trunks is deeply meaningful, as these people had once stood tall and proud in their strength and accomplishments, but were brought low by divine punishment. The image serves as a sobering reminder that all human pride and power are temporary, and that ultimate authority belongs to Allah alone.

This verse mentions other peoples who followed the same path of error and transgression: Pharaoh and those before him, as well as the overturned cities. The overturned cities refer to the cities of the people of Lot, which were completely destroyed and turned upside down as punishment for their shameful practices.

The verse establishes a pattern of historical precedent, showing that the rejection of divine guidance and persistence in sin leads inevitably to divine punishment. Pharaoh represents the height of earthly power and arrogance, yet even he could not escape divine justice. This serves as a warning to all who might think their worldly status protects them from accountability.

This verse describes how these various peoples and their leaders all disobeyed their respective messengers, consistently choosing rebellion over submission to divine guidance. Their disobedience was not merely passive rejection but active rebellion against the clear signs and messages brought by their prophets.

The pattern of disobedience across different times and places demonstrates a consistent human tendency to reject divine authority when it conflicts with worldly desires or established power structures. This verse serves to warn that the consequences of such disobedience are inevitable, regardless of the apparent strength or success of those who rebel.

This verse shifts to address humanity directly, referencing the great flood during the time of Prophet Noah. It states that when the waters rose and overflowed their bounds, Allah saved humanity by carrying them in the floating vessel (the ark). This verse connects all present humanity to that historical moment of divine salvation.

The phrasing suggests that all of humanity was symbolically carried in that ship, since the entire human race descended from the three sons of Noah who were saved in the ark. This creates a sense of shared heritage and divine mercy, reminding all people that their very existence is due to Allah's preservation of the righteous during that great trial.

This verse explains the purpose behind these historical accounts and divine interventions: to make them a reminder for humanity, and so that attentive ears might preserve these lessons carefully. The stories serve as 'days of Allah' - significant historical moments that demonstrate divine justice and mercy.

The mention of preserving ears refers to those who listen with consciousness and retain what they hear for guidance. These historical accounts form a continuous thread of divine lessons, connecting past events with present guidance and future accountability. The verse emphasizes that these are not mere stories but active guidance for those who choose to learn from them.

This verse marks a transition from historical accounts to future events, describing the moment when the trumpet will be blown with a single blast. This refers to the beginning of the Day of Judgment, when all worldly life will end and the resurrection will commence.

The emphasis on 'a single blast' highlights the instantaneous and universal nature of this event. Unlike the gradual destruction that befell previous nations, the end of the world will come suddenly and affect all creation simultaneously. This moment represents the ultimate fulfillment of all divine warnings and promises.

This verse describes how the earth and mountains will be lifted up and then crushed together with a single crushing blow. This cosmic event represents the complete transformation of the physical universe as part of the Day of Judgment, when all familiar structures and landmarks will be destroyed.

The image of mountains being crushed emphasizes the magnitude of this event, as mountains represent the most solid and permanent features of the earthly landscape. When even these are easily destroyed, it demonstrates the absolute power of Allah over all creation and the temporary nature of everything in this world.

This verse declares that on that day, the inevitable event will come to pass - referring to the Day of Judgment itself. After all the cosmic upheavals described in the previous verses, the main event that these were preparing for will finally occur: the judgment of all humanity.

The verse emphasizes that despite the magnitude of the cosmic changes, these are merely the preliminaries to the main event. The real significance lies not in the destruction of the physical world, but in the spiritual reckoning that follows, when all souls will face the consequences of their earthly choices.

This verse describes how the sky will split open and become fragile on that day. The heavens, which appear so solid and permanent from an earthly perspective, will be revealed as fragile and temporary when divine judgment arrives. This represents the dissolution of the entire cosmic order.

The splitting of the sky symbolizes the removal of all barriers between the earthly and divine realms. On the Day of Judgment, the hidden realities will become manifest, and the apparent solidity of the physical universe will be revealed as an illusion compared to the eternal reality of divine justice.

This verse describes angels positioned around the boundaries of the sky, and eight angels carrying the Throne of Allah above them. This provides a glimpse into the divine hierarchy and the organization of the heavenly realm that will become visible on the Day of Judgment.

The image of angels bearing the divine Throne represents the ultimate manifestation of divine authority and majesty. The specific mention of eight angels carrying the Throne emphasizes the perfection and order of divine governance, even in the midst of universal upheaval. This scene represents the eternal stability of divine authority contrasted with the temporary nature of worldly power.

This verse states that on that day, all people will be presented before Allah, with none of their secrets remaining hidden. Every thought, intention, and action that was concealed in worldly life will be exposed and made manifest for divine judgment.

The complete exposure of all secrets represents perfect divine justice, where judgment will be based on complete knowledge rather than partial understanding. This creates both fear for those who have hidden wrongdoing and comfort for those who maintained righteousness even in private, knowing that their hidden good deeds will also be revealed and rewarded.

This verse describes the joyful response of those who receive their record of deeds in their right hand, as they call out for others to read their book. They will be proud and eager to share their good record with others, wanting everyone to witness their success.

Receiving the record in the right hand symbolizes divine acceptance and success in the afterlife. The enthusiasm to share their record demonstrates the confidence and joy of those who lived righteously, knowing that their account will reflect their good choices and divine mercy. This represents the fulfillment of hope for those who maintained faith and righteous conduct.

This verse quotes the successful person as saying they had been certain they would meet their reckoning. This reflects a life lived with constant awareness of accountability to Allah, where all actions were guided by the knowledge that every deed would eventually be judged.

The certainty mentioned here represents the fruit of true faith - not merely intellectual belief, but a deep conviction that influenced daily behavior. Such people lived their worldly lives as preparation for the afterlife, making choices based on divine guidance rather than temporary worldly considerations. Their success in the afterlife validates their worldly approach to life.

This verse describes the reward of the successful ones: they will be in a life of complete satisfaction and pleasure. This represents the fulfillment of all legitimate desires and the absence of all discomfort, worry, or need. Their existence will be characterized by perfect contentment.

The description of 'pleasing life' indicates not just the absence of suffering, but the presence of positive joy and satisfaction. Every aspect of their existence will be designed to bring happiness and fulfillment, representing the perfect recompense for their worldly sacrifice and obedience to divine guidance.

This verse describes the elevated garden where the successful will reside, emphasizing the height and excellence of their dwelling place. The elevation represents both physical beauty and spiritual rank, indicating that their reward corresponds to their elevated spiritual status achieved through righteous living.

The garden represents the perfect environment for eternal happiness, combining natural beauty with divine blessing. The emphasis on height suggests both the honor of their position and the expansive view of divine mercy and beauty that will be available to them throughout eternity.

This verse describes how the fruits of Paradise will be easily within reach for the inhabitants, requiring no effort or difficulty to obtain. This represents the perfect fulfillment of all needs and desires without the struggle and effort that characterizes worldly life.

The ease of obtaining provisions in Paradise contrasts sharply with worldly life, where sustenance requires constant effort and is never guaranteed. This verse emphasizes that the afterlife reward includes not just good things, but the perfect ease and security in obtaining them, representing true freedom from all worldly concerns and limitations.

This verse contains divine instruction to the successful ones, telling them to eat and drink in complete satisfaction as reward for their good deeds in the days that have passed. This represents divine approval and blessing for their worldly choices and sacrifices.

The invitation to eat and drink with satisfaction represents the complete reversal of worldly deprivation and the fulfillment of divine promise. The reference to 'days that have passed' acknowledges that their current reward is directly connected to their previous choices, validating the wisdom of their worldly sacrifice for eternal benefit.

This verse contrasts the successful with those who receive their record in their left hand, describing their anguished cry wishing they had never been given their book. This represents complete despair and regret upon seeing the record of their worldly choices and their consequences.

The wish to never have received their record reflects the desire to remain in ignorance rather than face the truth of their spiritual condition. However, this wish comes too late, as the time for ignorance and self-deception has passed. The contrast with the joy of the successful emphasizes the importance of worldly choices in determining eternal consequences.

This verse continues the lament of the unsuccessful, expressing their wish that they had never been born. This represents the ultimate regret - wishing for non-existence rather than facing the consequences of their choices. The depth of their despair reflects the magnitude of their loss.

The wish for non-existence demonstrates that the punishment of the afterlife is so severe that it makes even existence itself seem undesirable. This extreme regret serves as a powerful warning about the importance of making righteous choices while the opportunity exists, before reaching a state where regret becomes permanent and useless.

This verse records their wish that death had been final and decisive, with no resurrection or afterlife accountability. They wish that their worldly death had ended their existence completely, sparing them from facing the consequences of their actions.

This wish reveals their fundamental misunderstanding of the nature of existence and divine justice. Their desire for death to be final demonstrates that they lived as if there were no accountability, making choices based only on immediate consequences rather than eternal ones. The impossibility of this wish serves to emphasize the inevitability of divine justice.

This verse continues their lament, expressing their realization that their wealth has not benefited them in their current predicament. All the material possessions and financial security they accumulated in worldly life have proven completely useless in the face of divine judgment.

The futility of wealth in the afterlife represents a fundamental reversal of worldly values. What seemed most important and securing in worldly life - material wealth - becomes completely irrelevant when facing spiritual accountability. This serves as a warning about the temporary nature of worldly success and the importance of investing in spiritual rather than merely material advancement.

This verse describes how all their worldly power and authority have completely perished and become useless. Whatever control, influence, or dominance they exercised in worldly life has been stripped away, leaving them completely powerless before divine judgment.

The loss of all authority represents another fundamental reversal between worldly life and the afterlife. Those who may have held positions of power, commanded respect, or controlled others find themselves completely helpless. This emphasizes that all worldly power is temporary and borrowed, while ultimate authority always remains with Allah.

This verse begins the divine command to the angels regarding the punishment of those who failed in their spiritual test. The instruction to 'seize him' represents the beginning of their punishment and the end of any possibility for escape or reprieve.

The divine command to the angels emphasizes that punishment in the afterlife is organized, deliberate, and inescapable. Unlike worldly punishments which might be avoided or appealed, divine justice is absolute and final. The involvement of angels in carrying out punishment demonstrates the perfect order and authority of divine justice.

This verse continues the divine command, instructing that the condemned person be bound with chains. This represents the complete restriction of freedom and movement, ensuring that there is no possibility of escape from the consequences of their choices.

The binding with chains symbolizes the natural consequences of spiritual slavery to sin and disobedience. Those who chose to be enslaved to their desires and worldly attachments find themselves literally enslaved in the afterlife. This represents the manifestation of spiritual reality in physical form.

This verse describes the condemned person being thrust into the blazing Fire, representing the ultimate punishment for those who rejected faith and righteous conduct. The Fire represents both physical torment and spiritual anguish resulting from separation from divine mercy.

The casting into Fire represents the natural destination of those who chose spiritual darkness over divine guidance. Just as their earthly choices led them away from divine light, their eternal destination reflects the logical conclusion of that spiritual journey. The Fire serves as both punishment and purification, representing divine justice in its absolute form.

This verse describes the condemned person being bound in a chain of seventy cubits length, emphasizing the severity and completeness of their restraint. The specific measurement indicates the thoroughness of their binding and the impossibility of escape.

The lengthy chain represents the accumulated weight of their earthly sins and the correspondingly severe nature of their punishment. Each link in the chain can be understood as representing the consequences of specific choices made during worldly life, now manifested as literal restraints in the afterlife.

This verse explains one of the fundamental reasons for this severe punishment: the condemned person never fed the poor or encouraged others to feed the needy. This highlights the critical importance of caring for those in need and fulfilling social obligations as part of spiritual development.

The failure to feed the poor represents a broader spiritual condition of selfishness and lack of compassion. Those who hoarded wealth while others suffered, or who failed to use their resources to help those in need, demonstrated a fundamental misunderstanding of their role as trustees of divine blessings. Their punishment reflects the gravity of ignoring social justice and human compassion.

This verse reiterates the condemned person's failure to encourage feeding the poor, emphasizing that they not only neglected this duty themselves but also failed to promote charity and social responsibility among others. This represents a compound failure of both personal practice and social leadership.

The emphasis on encouraging others highlights the importance of promoting good in society, not just practicing it individually. Those who had influence or resources but failed to use them to create a more just and compassionate society bear additional responsibility for the continuation of suffering that they could have helped alleviate.

This verse states that on this day, the condemned person will have no devoted friend to intercede for them. All the relationships and connections that seemed important in worldly life will prove unable to provide help or protection when divine judgment arrives.

The absence of friends and intercessors emphasizes the individual nature of spiritual accountability. While worldly success often depends on relationships and social connections, spiritual judgment is based solely on individual choices and divine mercy. This verse serves as a reminder to build one's relationship with Allah rather than relying solely on human relationships for security.

This verse describes that the only food available to the condemned will be foul refuse and corruption, representing the complete reversal of worldly luxury and pleasure. What seemed attractive and desirable in worldly life will be replaced by things that are repulsive and harmful.

The nature of this food represents the spiritual reality of sin manifested in physical form. Just as their earthly choices were spiritually corrupting, their eternal sustenance will reflect that corruption in tangible form. This serves as a warning about the hidden spiritual consequences of apparently attractive worldly choices.

This verse introduces a significant transition in the chapter, noting the similarity between this section and the final section of Surah Al-Waqi'ah. Both passages deal with the authentication of the Quran and response to those who deny its divine origin.

The connection between these passages emphasizes the consistent Quranic theme of defending the divine nature of the revelation against accusations of human fabrication. The parallel structure serves to reinforce the message through repetition and to address persistent doubts about the source and authority of the Quranic message.

This verse continues the literary connection with Surah Al-Waqi'ah, preparing the reader for the solemn oath that follows regarding the divine nature of the Quran. The reference to the positions where stars set creates anticipation for the magnificent oath that authenticates the divine origin of the revelation.

The preliminary reference serves to focus attention on the cosmic scale of the divine oath that follows, emphasizing that the authentication of the Quran is supported by evidence as vast and magnificent as the movement of celestial bodies across the heavens.

This verse declares that the Quran is indeed the word of a noble messenger, referring to both the Angel Gabriel who brought it from Allah, and Prophet Muhammad who conveyed it to humanity. The chain of transmission emphasizes the divine origin and faithful preservation of the message.

The description of the messenger as 'noble' emphasizes the honor and trustworthiness of both Gabriel and Muhammad in their roles as conveyors of divine revelation. This authentication is crucial for establishing the credibility and divine authority of the Quranic message against those who claimed it was of human origin.

This verse clarifies that the Quran is not the word of a poet, addressing one of the common accusations made against Prophet Muhammad by his opponents. They claimed he was merely a skilled poet creating impressive but humanly-crafted verses rather than receiving divine revelation.

The denial of poetic origin serves to distinguish divine revelation from human literary creativity, however skillful. While the Quran possesses unmatched literary beauty, its content and purpose transcend mere artistic expression to provide divine guidance and spiritual transformation. The verse challenges those who would reduce divine revelation to human artistry.

This verse continues the denial of false attributions, stating that the Quran is not the word of a soothsayer or fortune-teller. This addresses another common accusation that Prophet Muhammad was using supernatural but non-divine sources of information to create his teachings.

The distinction from soothsaying emphasizes that divine revelation is fundamentally different from occult practices or supernatural speculation. While the Quran contains knowledge of the unseen, this knowledge comes directly from divine omniscience rather than from contact with spirits, supernatural entities, or occult practices that characterized soothsayers.

This verse positively identifies the Quran as a revelation sent down from the Lord of all the worlds, establishing its true divine origin after denying the false attributions suggested by opponents. This represents the ultimate authentication of the Quranic message.

The title 'Lord of all the worlds' emphasizes the universal scope and authority of the divine source of the Quran. The revelation comes not from a limited or regional deity, but from the creator and sustainer of all existence, giving the Quranic message universal relevance and ultimate authority over all creation.

This verse begins a hypothetical statement about what would happen if Prophet Muhammad had fabricated any sayings and attributed them to Allah. The verse emphasizes the impossible nature of such an action by a true prophet and the severe consequences that would follow any such attempt.

The hypothetical nature of this statement serves to emphasize that such fabrication is unthinkable for a true messenger of Allah. The very suggestion is raised only to demonstrate its impossibility and to highlight the trustworthiness and integrity required of those chosen to convey divine revelation to humanity.

This verse describes how Allah would seize any messenger who fabricated divine revelations, taking him with the right hand, which symbolizes divine power and authority. This represents swift and certain divine justice against any corruption of the divine message.

The reference to seizing with the right hand emphasizes both the certainty and the honor of divine justice. Even a messenger, despite their elevated status, would face immediate divine intervention if they attempted to corrupt the revelation. This serves as the ultimate guarantee of the purity and authenticity of the Quranic message.

This verse continues the hypothetical punishment, stating that Allah would cut the life-vein of any messenger who fabricated revelations. This represents ultimate and final punishment, emphasizing the gravity of corrupting divine revelation and the impossibility of such corruption going unpunished.

The severity of this punishment underscores the sacred nature of divine revelation and the absolute requirement for faithful transmission. The verse serves as both a guarantee to believers that the revelation they receive is pure and authentic, and a warning to any who might consider tampering with divine guidance.

This verse emphasizes that no one would be able to prevent divine punishment if a messenger attempted to fabricate revelations. This highlights the absolute nature of divine authority and the futility of any human attempt to protect someone from divine justice.

The impossibility of preventing divine punishment serves as additional authentication of the Quranic message. Since Prophet Muhammad continued to receive and convey revelations throughout his life without facing such punishment, this serves as evidence that his message was genuinely divine rather than fabricated.

This verse declares that the Quran is indeed a reminder for the righteous - those who maintain consciousness of Allah and strive to follow divine guidance. For such people, the Quran serves as spiritual nourishment and direction for righteous living.

The specification that the Quran serves as a reminder for the righteous emphasizes that spiritual benefit from divine revelation requires a receptive heart and sincere intention. While the message is universal, its transformative power is most evident in those who approach it with humility and genuine desire for spiritual growth and guidance.

This verse acknowledges that Allah is fully aware that among the people are those who will reject and deny the Quranic message, regardless of the evidence presented to them. This divine knowledge encompasses both those who accept and those who reject guidance.

The acknowledgment of those who reject serves to comfort believers that opposition to divine truth is expected and does not invalidate the message. Divine omniscience includes complete knowledge of human responses to guidance, and the existence of deniers does not reflect any deficiency in the revelation but rather the exercise of human free will in spiritual matters.

This verse warns that the Quran will become a source of regret and anguish for those who deny it, when they eventually face the consequences of their rejection. The same revelation that brings guidance to believers will serve as evidence against those who rejected it.

The dual nature of the Quran - as blessing for believers and regret for deniers - emphasizes the crucial importance of one's response to divine guidance. The verse contains a prophetic warning that the very book they reject will serve as witness against them, making their denial a source of eternal regret when its truth becomes undeniably manifest.

This verse concludes the authentication by declaring that the Quran is indeed the certain truth - a reality as absolute and undeniable as existence itself. There is no mixture of falsehood in it, and its truth is complete and perfect.

The declaration of the Quran as 'certain truth' represents the culmination of all the arguments and evidence presented in the chapter. After addressing historical precedents, describing the Day of Judgment, and responding to accusations against the revelation, the chapter concludes with this absolute affirmation of the Quran's divine authenticity and perfect truth.

This final verse instructs Prophet Muhammad to glorify the name of his Lord, the Most Great, serving as both a conclusion to the chapter and a direction for proper response to divine revelation. The instruction to glorify Allah emphasizes that recognition of divine truth should lead to worship and praise.

The command to glorify Allah's name represents the natural and appropriate response to receiving and understanding divine revelation. After establishing the authenticity and authority of the Quranic message, the proper response is humble worship and acknowledgment of divine greatness. This verse mirrors the conclusion of Surah Al-Waqi'ah, creating a parallel structure that reinforces the message of divine authentication.
